thread.title: Dylan Crawford, U.S. Army All-American WR, receives long-awaited Oregon Ducks offer
thread.title_full: Dylan Crawford, U.S. Army All-American WR, receives long-awaited Oregon Ducks offer | OregonLive.com

author: Andrew Nemec | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: Dylan Crawford, U.S. Army All-American WR, receives long-awaited Oregon Ducks offer
text:
Hoping to add another receiver in the class of 2016, the Oregon Ducks have pursued several options, including once-committed Theo Howard , five-star wide receiver N'Keal Harry and four-star talent Javon McKinley .
But one player who has remained on the radar even without an offer has been U.S. Army All-American wide receiver Dylan Crawford, who listed Oregon in his top ten this summer .
Even then, the 6-foot-1, 175-pound pass-catcher, out of Rancho Santa Margarita, California, made it clear that the Ducks would jump to the forefront of his recruiting process by extending a scholarship.
"I like Oregon a lot. It's one of my dream schools," he said. "They'll definitely shoot up to the top with three or four others when they offer."
On Monday evening, after months of waiting, Crawford finally received the much-anticipated offer from the University of Oregon:
So grateful and excited to receive and offer to play at the University of Oregon! #GoDucks üê£‚úÖ pic.twitter.com/VhEKGRjIZv
‚Äî VI (@kekoa_cRAWford) October 21, 2015
Given the late offer, and the fact that the dynamic playmaker had eliminated the Ducks from contention in August , it will be interesting to see exactly how much ground the program still has to make.
At the time of the elimination, Crawford said Oregon would "easily" jump into his top group.
That belief will now be tested.
Oregon already has four-star talent Dillon Mitchell in the fold, but would love to add another big-time playmaker ‚Äì and Crawford would fit the bill.
The California prospect is rated by Rivals as the No. 90 prospect in the country, and he holds offers from Arizona, Arizona State, Miami (Fla.), Michigan, Stanford, Tennessee, UCLA, USC, Washington and Washington State.
Oregon has wanted to add at least one more wide receiver to the class for some time. Expect Crawford to be one to watch until he makes a decision.
-- Andrew Nemec
anemec@oregonian.com
@ AndrewNemec
